title: looking for chicago players
post_content: hello.i'm new to this forum (and keyboard forums in general) my main instruments are percussion & drum kit.the reason i'm here is to search for a keyboard player in the CHICAGO AREA (we rehearse out of the nw burbs)  i have already done a search on this forum and came up with nothing, so now basically i'm here to plea with anyone who might know a keyboard/organ/nord player in the Chicago area looking to play reggae...i have been to local music stores, craigslist. bandmix, reverbnation. and tons of local facebook musician groups. i have not found any keyboard players looking to play specificly roots and dub reggae (ie bands like fortunate youth, tribal seeds, iration, slightly stoopid, dirty heads - type stuff)the band i play with is called the concrete rootshttp://www.concreterootsmusic.com/we have music, video, and photos on our site (mastering a new song right now, should be up in the next couple days)

title: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: Hi,I've played piano for a long time in different setups. Since 3 years back I've been playing in a Rock n Roll band. I keep on struggling with my solo techniques. I do not have a problem playing the solos, I just want to know the theory behind it so that I can improve it in a correct way. I know it sounds weird but sometimes I feel uncomfortable because I do not know if this is "a correct way" to play it.I guess the best practice is to learn the scales from the beginning. Does anyone have any good tip or a good literature to practice from?Thanks in advance for advice's!/arvidsson

title: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: Check out The Jazz Piano Book by Mark Levine (It has given me a lot of good things to practice through the years.Good luck!

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: elektromin wrote:Check out The Jazz Piano Book by Mark Levine (It has given me a lot of good things to practice through the years.Good luck!Thanks for fast reply. Will look into that one. I'm not that much of a jazzy player but maybe that would help me in other genres as well?/a

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: Hi Arvidsson,The Mark Levine Book is very good, but it won't help at all with Rock'n Roll playing.Surely there must be lots of Rock/Rock'n Roll piano playing tutorials on You Tube ??Paul

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: It's always good to improve your learning, but a good solo is a good solo. There's no right way or wrong way to play solos. Remember that doing it your own way is what it's all about. If people like what you're doing, then you're doing it right!

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: Learn the pentatonic and blues scales. Search for tutorials on YouTube. I think in this kind of music that's all you need.

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: I like the Jamie Aebersold books especially the first three volumes.Also books by Mark Harrison are pretty good. One of his books is called the Pop Piano Book.

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: Hi Arvidsson,If you PM me with your regular email address I can sent you some stuff to help get you going mate.Ta,Paul

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: I forget who said it, but this is great advice:"I like to keep the melody going in my head as I play."It's nicely open about whether he means the melody of the song, or the melody you're playing in the solo.Which is to say:Chops are secondary to a good solo. If you can sing along with what you're playing, it's probably okay, and way better than just firing off a sequence of licks and hooks.As you work on your chops, the technique will become available in solos as well.

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: Nice trick, thanks

title: RE: Books about improving improvising solo's
post_content: monsterjazzlicks wrote:Hi Arvidsson,If you PM me with your regular email address I can sent you some stuff to help get you going mate.Ta,PaulHi Paul,can you send them also to me? I PM you my email.Thanks in advance!!Ramon

title: Are attachments tagged correctly?
post_content: I have a problem with the pdfs in this threadhttp://www.norduserforum.com/nord-stage ... tml#p37096Firefox (linux) does not recognise these as pdfs, so it offers to save them but not open them in a viewer.I guess that the files need to be tagged in a particular way to be opened as pdfs because firefox seems to have no problem in other sites.

title: RE: Are attachments tagged correctly?
post_content: Well spotted. The web server sends them with a MIME type ofapplication/octet-streaminstead ofapplication/pdf.

title: RE: Are attachments tagged correctly?
post_content: Hi,this is the default behaviour of the phpbb forum for security reasons. But I figured given the spam control here an exception for pdf files could be acceptable. So it should now have the correct mime-type if you can try again. Thanks!

title: RE: Are attachments tagged correctly?
post_content: Yes it works fine now. Thanks!

title: External Hard Drive Advice (Help ?)
post_content: Hi folks,i recently dropped my Seagate 500GB External Hard Drive consequently wiping everything off it !!  Though luckily i did have everything backed up on my PC and on another External Hard Drive.i replaced the broken HD with a TeraByte and wanted to purchase something to protect it against another accident.  i have found hard/soft cases to store/carry the HD in, but is there anything which you can use to cover/protect it permanently at all times ??  i was thinking of covering the HD with lots of bubble-wrap (or similar) which would work, though would not be particularly stylish or aesthetically pleasing.Here are a couple i found on ebay :-http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/110749949105? ... 1423.l2649http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/2-5-PROTECTIV ... 637wt_1172Welcome to any suggestions............Best,Paul Seaman

title: RE: External Hard Drive Advice (Help ?)
post_content: That looks like a nice case that should protect it against drops; good price too and the edge is pretty thick so should absorb the shock if you drop it. Should sure last longer than bubblewrap.I have a case like that for a logic analyzer and it's pretty sturdy.

title: RE: External Hard Drive Advice (Help ?)
post_content: Another option is to use a solid state drive. It would be much more resistant to shock and vibration than a spinning disk, regardless of what you surround it with. They are more expensive, but they are quicker too. As you found out, two backups are better than one!

title: RE: External Hard Drive Advice (Help ?)
post_content: Mr_-G- wrote:Another option is to use a solid state drive. It would be much more resistant to shock and vibration than a spinning disk, regardless of what you surround it with. They are more expensive, but they are quicker too. As you found out, two backups are better than one!i bought the Seagate HD in a panic to get everything backed up asap !!  But if i ever need to purchase one again, i am definately going to go for the Solid State option.  Thanks.

title: RE: External Hard Drive Advice (Help ?)
post_content: mjbrands wrote:That looks like a nice case that should protect it against drops; good price too and the edge is pretty thick so should absorb the shock if you drop it. Should sure last longer than bubblewrap.Thanks MJB,i think i will go for this design of case mate.i looked into Sky Storage, but 500GB worth works out to be astronomically extortionate !!Paul

title: Header Graphic Design Contest
post_content: Hi all,this forum is now two and a half years old and from time to time some little redesign is great in particular, I thought of starging a little contest for designing a new, full-image header graphic to replace the current very basic one. And since I've seen several gifted photoshoppers around already, there might be someone interested in participating.So here are the rules for the contest and those interested in participating:1) The graphic should be of the format 728x90 Pixel (max. width could be 810px)2) Needs to work with the unicolor (or gradient) menu bar3) Color scheme could be adapted (header background, menu bar, but also for the rest of the site)... suggestions welcome!4) The word "Nord User Forum" OR "norduserforum.com" needs to appear on the graphic.5) It needs to blend with a either unicolour or gradient (like it is now, 90x1px, see attached file) background in any colour in order to allow for the rounded corners and flexible width of the header bar6) It needs to be in gif/jpeg/png format. Animated GIF is possible but in this case a static version needs also be available (for the content pages).Basically, some crazy Synth Stuff would be fun, obviously related to the Nord brand but must not be completely Nordish.I will see what I can throw in as a goodie for the winner. If there are several suggestions I will start a poll to vote for the winner.Let me know what you think and I hope for some good propositions!!CheersJohannesCurrent Background Gradient:

title: Outages / New Domain and Server Host

title: Trouble with filenames after download.. "%20"?
post_content: Hi,I'm having an issue with filenames whenever I download a .nsmp file or a .ns2p file from the forum.  Any file I download ends up with "%20" in place of any blank spaces included in the filename.For Example:I download "Ambient str art.nsmp" and in my finder (Mac Pro OSX 10.6.8) the filename appears as: Ambient%20str%20art.nsmp.Anybody else having this issue?  I then have to go in and delete the %20's from all the filenames!Thanks,Dan

title: RE: Trouble with filenames after download.. "%20"?
post_content: Yes I also have this. As you say, the %20's need to be replaced with spaces before it works. Would be nice if the sound manager did this automatically.

title: RE: Trouble with filenames after download.. "%20"?
post_content: Hi Dan,indeed as Darren says, you can manually replace them by spaces.But since this issue comes up from time to time, will look into maybe a way to do this softwarewise on the forum. It should work on windows, but would be best to have a version that works everywhere. So could you maybe tell me which OS you are using (reply or PM)?While spaces should in theory not be in any filename that is used on the web or different OSes, they are useful for Nord Files since otherwise the name does not get displayes as nice on the display so it makes sense to have them (also I just found out that if you use "_" instead, the displayed name is unchanged).Will see what can be done, until then, renaming is your friend!CheersJohannes

title: RE: Trouble with filenames after download.. "%20"?
post_content: Hey Mac Users- here's a simple script for "Automator" (an app you'll find in your Applications folder) that will replace the "%20" in any filename with a space.Open Automator, load this script, then in a finder window highlight one or as many files as you'd like to change the names of and hit "run."  Presto- they'll all be renamed with spaces in place of the %20.If you prefer to keep the original file and it's original name, then add a "Duplicate Finder Items" to the script.

title: RE: Trouble with filenames after download.. "%20"?
post_content: Thanks for your help everybody.  I'm on OSX 10.6.8 for the record.  I have just been changing the filenames manually, but the Automator script will be very helpful!Thanks again!

title: Getting back into it after serious injury
post_content: Hi All. This is my first visit to the forums in a year or so. Around this time last year the band I play with, The Back Issues (check us out on youtube), were flying pretty high. We had just played our most prestige gig to date at the holy grail of British venues, The Cavern in Liverpool and requests were coming in for us to play at other venues around Britain and Ireland.Then tragedy struck. I was making my way to work on my Vespa along the route I have been taking every day for years. It was a glorious early summer morning and I had let the usual rush hour traffic die down before setting out. Mine was the only vehicle for as far as I could see both in front and behind me. Coming to an offslip, I slowed down and indicated to merge with the traffic to my right to continue my journey. Another driverin the lane I was merging with flashed me in and before pulling out, I did my lifesaver over my right shoulder just in time to see a car inches from me and in no hurry to slow down. I just had time to think "Oo-er, I'm a goner here", then hearing and feeling the impact and the last thing I remember was seeing the floor of my scooter in front of my face and thinking "what is that doing there" before coming round in the middle of the road.To cut a very long story short, I had a fractured spine along with other spinal and muscularskeletal injuries. As yoou can imagine, I haven't played since.Now I'm about ready to start practicing again (in mky own home, not our rehearsal room - yet!). Its going to be a long, painful, drawn-out recovery but I'm determined to pick up where I left off. And its great to be back here again.Now, its time to hunt down a few sounds...

title: RE: Getting back into it after serious injury
post_content: I hear you mate. 6 years ago I cut both my hands and my right wrist while catching falling glass from a broken window (I know...how dumb was that?) severed three ligaments in my right arm and couldn't move my thumb or wrist. Took a while but I made it back to music, couldn't live without it. So welcome back to you.

title: RE: Getting back into it after serious injury
post_content: Welcome back, Mickrick! Great to hear from you! Good luck with your recuperation.Just got my sight back on my left eye after an operation. Retina was falling off, due to passing my "best-before-date". Still can't read sheet music. Never could.

title: RE: Getting back into it after serious injury
post_content: Thanks guys. The best part was when I asked the doctor if I would be able to play the piano. He said "of course". "Great"I replied, "I wasn't able to play it before". It's the way I tell 'em.

title: Warmup and maintenance procedure
post_content: Hello,Here is a warmup and maintenance procedure for intermediate keyboard players.All remarks are welcome.I need your advices : Am I doing something stupid ? Does this makes sense ?Intended use :For a quick warmup before a gig, as an everyday exercise to keep fingers and head ready to play, or for education purpose to learn some essential things about harmony, around the cycle of fourths.Procedure :- Switch on a rythm or a metronome, set it at a speed you can play everything in time.- For each of the following key : C, Db, A, Eb, using the major diatonic scale, do :Play the IV7 chord in root position with one hand.Go up 4 degrees (inclusive), you now play the vii7 chord in 2nd inversion. You have just moved your 2 highest fingers 2 steps down (easy).Go up again, do that 7 times in total and you'll reach the root degree I. You have played all degrees.Improvise with the other hand, doing bass or melody alternatively, change hand and go to step 1.Alternative :- Start on degree ii with a ii7 chord instead of IV7.- Make arpeggios and pumps with chords, go up/down the scale every two pitches, go chromatic.- Practice your timing, change chords on different 16th positions.- Try some alterations, change degrees to go minor / major.- Take a different keyboard (organ ?) and different rhythms / stylesRecommendations :- Know what degree you are playing, what chord (color) you are playing.- Count measures in your head while you play ("1 e & a 2 ...").- Sing while you play- Locate the "passing 4" and the blue notes.- Record yourself, check what's wrong from a listener's point of viewSchedule :- 10 mn everyday is better than 50 minutes a week.

title: Passwords
post_content: Sorry to make my first post here a complaint, but I am completely shocked that the forum administrators would commit such a blatant security infraction as the sending of unencrypted passwords back with the confirmation email. This is a BAD PRACTICE! Even more ironic is how your registration process talks about using "secure passwords", and adds the "may the force be with you!" message if you use a strong password.But probably the most frightening thought is that if you are able to send an unencrypted password back to the user, it is likely that you are STORING the passwords in your database unencrypted as well. Again, BAD PRACTICE! Your MySQL database could be hacked in less than 30 seconds, and each and every email-password combination would soon be the property of identity thieves.OK, I've gotten that off my chest. I will now participate in the discussions about your awesome keyboards.Peace,VB

title: RE: Passwords
post_content: Hi Vinslom,I appreciate your comment. I agree it is not "best practice" to send them via mail. I changed it some time ago since there were many requests to send passwords via mail as many users seem to have forgotten there passwords, and having it for a record in the mail seemed the easiest way to avoid countless change requests etc. But I agree in general it would be better without, just a way of convenience (and used on around one third of the forums I visit) vs. security, and given this is "only" a forum and does not contain (most likely) sensitive issues so the convenience factor seemed to dominate. But it might be good to go back to the standard.Nevertheless, the passwords ARE stored encrypted in the database, the only time they are processed unencrypted is precisely when sengind the confirmation mail.Also, we always keep all elements of this forum's software up to the most recent updates and security standards (also best practice, but nevertheless not the case on many other forums), and security is top priority. As for the password, we can easily remove sending out passwords.Best regards,Johannes

title: RE: Passwords
post_content: Vinslom Bardy wrote:Sorry to make my first post here a complaint, but I am completely shocked that the forum administrators would commit such a blatant security infraction as the sending of unencrypted passwords back with the confirmation email. This is a BAD PRACTICE! Even more ironic is how your registration process talks about using "secure passwords", and adds the "may the force be with you!" message if you use a strong password.But probably the most frightening thought is that if you are able to send an unencrypted password back to the user, it is likely that you are STORING the passwords in your database unencrypted as well. Again, BAD PRACTICE! Your MySQL database could be hacked in less than 30 seconds, and each and every email-password combination would soon be the property of identity thieves.OK, I've gotten that off my chest. I will now participate in the discussions about your awesome keyboards.Peace,VBThanks for making this security flaw public.  Much more secure airing it out in public rather than send a private message to the moderator.

title: RE: Passwords
post_content: @walkerdata: Nah, my posting this doesn't change anything. Hackers already have each and every phpBB installation cataloged and documented. In IT security, it's better to draw light to the issues amongst the users, because the bad guys already know what is being pointed out. The more users we have that are educated on these issues, the better off the legitimate online community will be.@johannes: Good to hear that your password field is encrypted. MySQL makes that step super easy. I guess I can understand your rationale for sending passwords, but perhaps you could just do this only upon request (not upon initial registration), and only after the user has been warned about the potential dangers of receiving an email with their username and password. Just a thought from one geek to another.Peace,VB

title: RE: Passwords
post_content: Hi VB,thanks for the rephrasing, makes my reply much easierSo I just changed it and now no more password will be send. If you don't know the email address you used, PM me!Cheers, Johannes

title: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: Hi everybody,As I think I wrote before in a previous post, I recently joined a jazz/blues club band from my university. The thing is that I actually do not hear a lot of jazz and blues.  Here's the story on the why: I wanted to join a band/club to force me to practice since I was starting to feel my skills were being lost due to the lack of practice. At first I was going to enter Rock club, but it was too late for me and my city right now is highly dangerous. So I saw that jazz club was sort of early, ending at 1600 and I decided to enter. I also entered because a friend of mine who is a guitarist insisted I joined because they had no keyboard player, so I would have no "competition"In the club we have a teacher that guides us but basically what we play and do is up to us. in this semester we are going to adapt several mexican golden era movie themes to jazz, starting with this one.[youtube][/youtube]and also we are selecting a few blues songs and we are going to interpret them. With that repertoire we are going to assist a jazz festival on november and play at several events of the university.So first, what jazz/blues artists/albums/pieces do you recommend that are fine examples of how a keyboardist should play?Also any advice in particular about developing in such an environment, things (not) to do or any tips?I saw the other topic about bebop scales and I am going to check out some of the things recommended in there, just FIY.

title: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: There are tons of people to listen to. However two pianists in particular stand out in my mind: Dr. John and Gene Harris. They will get your ear geared up and give you ideas playingwise.Really not sure on any method books but I'm sure if you google their names you may be able to find transcriptions and other books either by them or focusing on their style.Hope this helps.

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: Thanks!I will try and get some music from them. I bought a latin jazz compilation with a Return to Forever DVD, so I guess I am getting started.Playing wise I feel like I am quickly catching up, as I had never even played blues or latin style music. But I am feeling that it is most about just improvising and what you think sounds good. That plus learning to play in a band scenario, where most people do not notice you until your blazing solos. Good thing is that the band I am in fits in very well, it is a very cool ambient and we all understand each other decently.

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: The first three volumes of the Jamie Abersold series have a wealth of information. That is  great starting point. hope that helps or buy a "Real Book".

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: +1 for Jamie Aebersold. It'll get you going with improvising over simple blues form and then you can take it from there!

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: +1 for Jamie Aebersold indeed.

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: Hi G,Definately the BEST thing you can do (right now !!) is to transcribe the MILES DAVIS solo on SO WHAT (Kind of Blue album).  It is a fairly easily solo to transcribe in that there are no chord changes to worry about (just a semitone shift in tonal center), it is diatonic, no double-time passages, quite short, very melodic, rhythmically non-complex, and obviously single-note (with it being a horn !!).If you can work it out in your head then that would be BRILLIANT and ultimately rewarding !!  Though if you need a piano then thats totally fine and you will learn so much from this task.  TRANSCRIBING a definative (though simple) solo like this (i promise you) will infulence you for many years.Best,Paul

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: PS. Dont just transcribe or listen to PIANO PLAYERS !!!  Most of what i have learned comes directly from Drummers, Bassists and Saxophonists !!

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: Thanks for the advice, I can´t believe its been a little over a year since I actually started my musical journey. I feel like I have advanced quite a lot, specially rhythmically.A thing I found a while ago is a book of John Coltrane licks. Those are superb to start doing solos since you can get a lot of ideas from his various licks, and they also make good exercises.I know what you say about not listening to piano players, specially because it can be too intimidating!! listening to guys like Bill Evans or Dave Brubeck to Chick Corea and Hiromi is totally intimidating, it makes me believe I can't even play the piano. Then there are times where with my fellow bandmates we play very simple songs, like All Blues and people praise us for our playing. Sometimes playing simple stuff (like a trumpet or a sax would do) can be quite rewarding.Saludos,GustavoPS: I've already learned All Blues, So What, Blue in Green and also made *some* attempts at recreating some of the solos.

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: Cee wrote:+1 for Jamie Aebersold. It'll get you going with improvising over simple blues form and then you can take it from there!I didn't remember this one piece of advice but coincidentally I just got the first two "volumes" a week ago!!

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: If you are looking to further develop your RHYTHM then if you can join a local percussion group that would really help to sort you out.  i played Timpani in a very amauter orchestra and it really helped to improve my timing etc.  Or buy a cheap pair of drumsticks and a rubber drum pad and sit in your room drumming along to records.  If you did this 2/3 times per week the strengths gained will start to transfer their way into your piano playing.  And you will have a greater awareness and appreciation for the drummer in your band.Tapping your foot on beats TWO and FOUR will really benefit your swing playing (and help you to lock-in with the drummer).Don't worry about feeling intimidated by the great pianists.  The more you transcribe them, and the more you improve, and the more you listen, they will CONTINUE to sound better and better !!  What i mean is as you develop you then begin to notice more and more greatness in their playing, so the learning curve never stops !!!  ie. The more you learn, the more you realize you don't know !!If people in your audience are complimenting your playing then you are obviously doing something correct and moving in the right direction !!If you practice 3/4 days per week then that is good and you will DEFINATELY improve for sure.  It is impossible not to !!

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: +1 with Paul, great advices IMHOPaul is just right about how rewarding a drumming experience can be.In september I began to play the drumset in a band with my local music school.Starting from scratch, for me it's about two times 10 minutes 4 days a week on technical rudiments,  15 minutes 3 days a week practicing/learning the tunes, and ~1 hour per week with the band.I listen to tunes from the drummer's perspective, found that "air" drumming with only my hands/knees and feet/floor helped me a lot for coordination.The learning curve goes fast at the beginning and it's very rewarding and addictive (always want to spend more time, more often).Have a good teacher (or drummer friend), a good teaching method ... you might want to play both instruments in two different bands !

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: Frantz is totally 100% correct here.Tot much of music tuition/practice is spent with an emphasis on HARMONY !!  And RHYTHM is much too often overlooked.There is a BRILLIANT book by (i think) drummer Louis Bellson and i know tons of musicians in London who practice from this book.  And many of these are non-drummers !!!A very good drummer once told me that it is not just the drummers role to keep the TIME in the band.  EVERYONE in the band should have equally good TIME !!!

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: one of the good things to practice in swing style, regardless of what instrument you play, is the following:Use a metronome, set it to the half speed (so if the tune is 160, set it to 80) Now let it start, but see the clicks as the 2 and 4 of the bar. (1 - click - 3 - click...)play your entire song incl. soloing on this. You will perhaps not get this in the beginning, but it is a real good exercise for your timing to keep this going and not shift into the click coming on 1 and 3.I learned this from my first trombone jazz teacher many years agon and still use it.And stay with simple songs! Don't bother with overcomplicated song and chord structures, get simple things working first.

title: RE: Advices for a jazz/blues newbie?
post_content: Just today I had some time to view the Jamey Aebersold Volumes I I got, my god I cannot believe the quantity of Volumes that guy has written!! Just impressive. But will take the Volume I recommendation and take it slowly at my own pace.@Joe thanks for that tip, its really usefull, have been doing that for some time, but I still every now and then get confused and do it (click - 2 - click - 4) but with practice I gotta take that eventually.Right now I am trying to improve my technique play real legato slowly (which has proven to be hard for me) and play some scales to practice posture, fingering and such.

title: Need help organize my study
post_content: Dear all, this is a newbie question so pls bare with me and my long post.I have been playing classic piano for about a year (with teacher first) but now alone by myself with couple of books and play along from Jamey Aebersold.My current abilities:1. Can read music for both hands2. Can play triads (all inversions) in major, minor, diminished, and augmented3. Can play 7th chords major7, minor7, dominant7 and learning to play dim7 also practicing 7th chords inversions.4. Can play music from lead sheet without much of the problems (if the chord not too hard)5. Can play major and minor scales (melodic minor)My resources:1. Jazz Piano Book by Mark Levine2. Jazz Improv: How to Play It and Teach It by Jimmy Amadie --> Haven't started yet3. Harmonic Foundation for Jazz and Popular Music by Jimmy Amadie --> This book teaches how to construct chords using two hands4. Connecting Chords with Linear Harmony (Jazz Book) by Bert Ligon --> Haven't started yet5. Vol. 1, How To Play Jazz & Improvise (Book & CD Set) (Play- a-Long) by Jamey Aebersold6. Play a long from Jamey Aebersold7. Bill Evans Play a longMy problems is that with all this great books and play a long, I still have no solid practice routines to fully utilize them. I am now practicing scales chord (inversions) and play a long (occasionally). My previous routine is that in the morning, I practice scale and chords (about 45 mins before go to work). In the evening, practice book number 1, 3, and 5 but cannot do it now since have to split piano time with my son practiceand have to go bed with him. So, now I have about 1 hour in the evening and in the morning but really don't know how to use it wisely.If anyone can help, it will be greatly appreciated.Thank you very much in advance for your kind help

title: RE: Need help organize my study
post_content: Hello,I would like to have some routines too.Maybe it's somewhere, in a "ready to use package", with different levels / abilities.That's a pleasant idea.If we were to build that, we would probably :- write a complete list all the rudiments (exercices),- sort them by levels/abilities (basic, intermediate, advanced)- factorize (chose elements you want to keep)- draw some links between dependent rudiments (what should be done before what)- write down 3 routines that chain the rudiments in a smart way (progressive, not boring), maybe a 5 minute routine, a 15 mn, and a full.This is an evolving process, has to be adapted to the person, but building one in common seems very interesting.I must say that this is very inspired by Tommy Igoe's "Great Hands For a Lifetime" DVD, for drummers.If we do not find one equivalent for piano and keyboard players, then we could start building it here ?

title: RE: Need help organize my study
post_content: Thank you very much for your ideas, it might be very naive question for any anyone who has all the tricks in their bags but for someone who has word "beginner" as a prefix like me, anything would help. I can play a piano all day with all the songs  that I like and still not learning anything 555.

title: RE: Need help organize my study
post_content: Grasoon, Hi again, hope you're not too far, I come back with more questions to your questionThere is a practice procedure in Jamey Abersold's handbook page 11 for instance.There is Hanon's exercise too (http://www.hanon-online.com/)But I think this is not global, in a sense that a routine should include both the technical and the harmonic elements we want to learn & keep in our fingers and in our head.Let's start a list of tunes with the widest harmony and technical diversity.- Bumble bee flight / Entry of gladiators (chromatic scale, left hand pump)- Georgia on my mind (major / minor modulation, go through all degree of a scale with 7th)- Autumn leaves (circle of fourth progression)- Girl from Ipanema (modulation with 3 scales)- So What, Cantlaoupe island, September second (jazz, modal jazz)We could include a reggae to practice hand independance, the left hand in counter time.We could include other signature, triplets ...I'm certainly for from my own goal, you're more advanced than me in the abilities, please tell me what you think.

title: RE: Need help organize my study
post_content: I fully recommend you to get some kind of band, even if its just for rehearsing and jamming. I find that helped me a lot, since I had peer pressure to actually play something.One way is to find a music school that teaches Jazz (since it looks like you want to play that style), they will probably have some kind of ensemble so that you get used to play in a band context. Doing so is very different than playing alone.Also, sometimes its not very important what notes you play as long as they belong to the scale (specially in jazz). It is more important to have a correct rythm so try practicing with drum loops and metronomes.Just my two cents,Gustavo

title: RE: Need help organize my study
post_content: I switched from bass to organ in 2007 when I found the Nord C1 at age 47.The secret is to practise every day in a stuctured manor. 15 mins a day is superior to 75 min on sunday.And to practice so slow that you can play it right.And accept that it takes time.But age is not the major obstacle - finding time every dat is the bigger real challenge.Go for it !!!!

title: RE: Need help organize my study
post_content: flmc59 wrote:I switched from bass to organ in 2007 when I found the Nord C1 at age 47.The secret is to practise every day in a stuctured manor. 15 mins a day is superior to 75 min on sunday.And to practice so slow that you can play it right.And accept that it takes time.But age is not the major obstacle - finding time every dat is the bigger real challenge.Go for it !!!!Totally agreed!!!Usually I am so busy with college and work, plus my girlfriend that I ended up practicing about 2 hours only 2 days a week (thursday and saturday). Now that I am on vacations I've been practicing just scales and chords to improve my technique (I've been sort of self taught but now I got a real classical piano technique-focused teacher and told me how I was playing wrong) and let me tell you that with practicing a little everyday I feel like I advance more than playing for long only one day a week.Saludos,Gustavo

title: RE: Need help organize my study
post_content: As a beginner, don't practice to play fast stuff, play slow but evenly. Practice scales and arpeggios slowly, until they sound smooth and even. The biggest trap is to "practice" what you already can play and to play that on and on. Look for more difficult scales and arpeggios or II-V-I  structures to play them really slowly and evenly to get that into your fingers.... Get a metronome.

title: RE: Look out any window (of your studio)
post_content: frantzkb wrote:Do you have the surfing board on top of the roof ?Johannes wrote:Awesome! Had exactly the same question, where's the (other) board?? This way you could hit the North (ehh,Nord) Wave...Nope, sorry to disapoint. Just a bed, my camera, my keyboard, and a computer that serves them both (and about to die, after 5 years of backpack treatment...).Btw, I'd like to advertise a great product, 100% artisanal : do you see the little black and silverish box atop the NS2 (on the organ section) ? It is an sd-card midifile player/recorder ! It's so simple, it takes less than one second to switch on and start recording... So I keep the technical hassle to an absolute minimum when improvising music (which is my trade). It has one power input, two midi connectors, one sd-slot and that's it. Direct rec, play, stop, file select and transpose buttons, and no menu ! It can even record for days at a time so I don't even have to think to press rec when I sit myself at the keyboard... Well, in theory, that is. I suppose that would work well in a conventional studio, but in the van, the fluctuating power makes it freeze eventually... But not being able to record for more than a couple of hours in a row is the only complaint I have. And of course it is so simple that it records everything that comes through the midi input without discerning: all channels, absolutely all midi message and sysEx... So I didn't even need to look at my NS2 implementation chart or worry about anything of the sort. Then the midi file goes into the computer. A music software (Reaper) allows me to edit the midi, play it back to the NS2 and record the audio from the NS2 on a parallel track. Next step: still in the same project, mastering of that track, then reapers renders directly in FLAC format, and I can upload a perfect improvisation to Bandcamp within minutes... It's a great and quick workflow that, thanks to this little box, lets me turn on the computer and start worrying about Windows only after i'm done playing ! (Yes I run Windows on a Mac, because, er, I'm the rebel type. 8D)Apparently the circuitry and firmware are a German open source project and the box and interface are an English piano freak's project. So they found each other on the internet, and then I found them. Here's the English website for the final product:http://www.sdmidicontroller.com/. That man is very friendly, btw. Or Google for "SD MIDI CONTROLLER" and find the project at different stages of manufacture.

title: Piano Versions
post_content: Just a little speech on Nord piano versions:In my Ex I have loaded several versions of pianos.The first obvious difference between versions 4 and 5.30  is that the electric pianos are considerably smaller.5-7 MB.However in version 5.30 the updated electric pianos are 10-14 MB.There is also a difference in acoustic piano sizes..{Sure the resonance is not as advanced but it is noticeably louder in 4.00?}. On the other hand  there are also quality differences.The Acoustic and Electric Pianos have more punch and velocity in 5.30. The Frequency response is generally smoother for most pianos in 5.30.In 4.00 for example there is a problem note that occurs in Studio Grand close XL on A3 at certain velocities.These kind of notes are almost non-existent in 5.30.Mixing and matching pianos  allowed me (an EX user)  to use more at once.!Older piano versions will not work on the Nord Stage 2!Anybody else have something to add?

title: RE: Piano Versions
post_content: Heres a very simple description of some of the newer grand samples.Bright Grand:Gives that punch needed in many styles and live playing.Xl Imperial:Large sound, dark,great presence through all velocities.Grand Lady D:nice for classical or ambient music.(however I feel It lacks alot in the softer end which a true Stienway produces).The rest are described quite well on the nord site.

title: RE: Piano Versions
post_content: Some Eq suggestions:in random order Bosendorfer/Stienway settingshttp://www.norduserforum.com/post22706.html?hilit=pianoReggae eq#p22706http://www.norduserforum.com/post13264. ... gae#p13264Boogie woogiehttp://www.norduserforum.com/post16269. ... lit=boogiewoogie#p16269

title: Piano Versions
post_content: The Rain piano with string resonance and some Eq is a nice way to get a dark piano tone.Add some reverb and it's perfect for Christmas background music.The Romantic upright also has a nice ring.But for something powerfull use the Queen.

title: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: Hi everybody.Im a graphic design student from Denmark. As my final exam I'm doing a study of the Nord keyboards' identity. As a part of my work I'm doing a lot of research, to get to know the brand and it's values.What is your opinion is on the Nord brand and it's product? And what do you think Nord does better/or worse than other keyboard manufactures?I really hope you can help me getting to know the brand a little moreBest regardsSteffenhttp://www.steffensteffen.com

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: Wow. That question could get you opinions the size of novels from the gearheads on this forumI'll try to give you the points I feel are most important.Better than othersBuilt for performance (playing rather than programming).Rock solid quality.Musical sounds.Lots of knobs = quick access to the important stuffRed.Born in Stockholm. Like me.Worse than othersBuilt for performance (playing rather than programming).Limited functionality.Puny display.

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: Not that it matters too much, but I am curious: are you doing this under Nord's knowledge?I wondered whether any brand would be happy of being criticised and bashed publicly as the Nord identity seems to be something that they already have worked out very successfully by themselves.By the way, there is no need to post the above in every forum, as there is an "off topic" forum for matters like these.

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: Hi there Steffen!The short anwser from my exerience would be:They are made to play live on stage with a solid sound.

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: What is your opinion is on the Nord brand and it's product?Excellent.And what do you think Nord does better than other keyboard manufactures?Producing superb gigging instruments.Supporting their community of users with software updates and new samples etc.Best of luck with your project!Cheers,Jamesx

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: All stuff you probably know:  Nord, is well known for it's red keboard's and  their great funtionality.1.Nord started its reputation in 1995 - 1998 with the creation of the nord lead,the very first vitual analog synth.2.Since then they have applied their expertise to  Organ, Synth, Digital piano and even drum machines.3.Their instrument's are focused on the performing artist.<(most Obvious)Overall Nord has,so to speak "sold themselves" to the world,My opinion:I have an Ex and find it fit's my need's very well.It gives me 3 Organ model's great for a gig or stage performance.A NICE LESLIE TOUCH is provided.The acoustic Piano's have a very natural timbre.Not to start a whole disscusion over, but compared to other keyboard's in the same range nord's have far more piano variety.For example The nord sample library includes sampled piano's from Yamaha's to Bosendofers.Nord also samplesuprightswhich seem to be lacking in other keboard's.The electric Grand's include a CP-80 and a custom electric grand with CP-80 pickup's.Their are also good electric piano's,a wurly and a clavinet.Nord get's 10 point's for their effect's section.It's even improved in the stage 2!.Even the relatively simple synth section gives me the funtionality needed for Crushing  synth lead's and bass'sand even soft flowing pad's.agree?

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: Mr_-G- wrote:I wondered whether any brand would be happy of being criticised and bashed publicly as the Nord identity seems to be something that they already have worked out very successfully by themselves.I have personally welcomed several academic investigations about the company I work for; they can sometimes provide valuable input. To me, it's probable that Clavia would also welcome it.And to be honest: there is quite a bit of Nord bashing going on even among us loyal followers...

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: It's red and clean with lots of knobs...the more knobs the better. the more red the better....

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: Nord means efficiency and quality.Everything falls under the hands and sounds "alive".... plus you can touch wood (pitch bend) and rock (theresinwheel) while playing

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: Kære nabo!What is your opinion is on the Nord brand and it's product?Brilliant! The name is cool! The color stands out, seen on almost every TV channel now. Real artists use them. The high price shows it's a premium product. Don' change a thing! (I'm also born in Stockholm.)And what do you think Nord does better/or worse than other keyboard manufactures?+ : Ease of use! Brilliant sounds. Excellent software. Outstanding flexibility. Portability. Makes you feel really professional. It's a musical time machine!- : None. Well ... Perhaps too many models to chose from. Short model life span. Price.... but it's a simple premium product that does the job well, just like Absolut Vodka.Don' change a thing, Clavia!

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: Nord is a player's board, you sit down, switch it on, start playing and enjoy. For me its the path of least resistance to bring my music from the fingertips to my ears.Visually a Nord board is very recognisable, you know one when you see one. It's not a piece of furniture or a decoration element, so at least for a non-performing home musician like me it is purely a non-compromising choice in favor of music. And I like it that way, so I'm not dissing Nord's visual appearance or (absolutely not!) saying I would love it even more if it were more like a Clavinova home modelIgnoring the design aspects, perhaps there is some similarity in Nord and Apple brands and what makes people choose them and love or hate them? There is the same air of no-compromises-to-please-the-masses attitude and you cannot always pick either purely based on the tech specs or certainly not the price, but there's something in both that just ... well, works so well for the intended purpose.

title: RE: Study of the Nord visual identity – Opinion
post_content: The Nord is Musical Instrument not a electric mashine,you feel it,is real.is not a computer is not a software.You feel like you play on acoustic intrumentIs alive!

title: loop pedal or other guitar pedals for Keyboards?
post_content: Im planning to get a loop pedal for recording backing tracks.Which ones would be best for this?Also are there any guitar pedals that would go well with synths and pianos for effects?(other than wah,tremolo,delay and phaser)?

title: RE: loop pedal or other guitar pedals for Keyboards?
post_content: Hi Titanium.To answer your 2nd question, you can of course connect any keyboard's output through a volume pedal. I did that to emulate a 'swell' effect with a cheap Casio keyboard's organ sound (well, with Clavia keyboards, you have a dedicated swell pedal jack, so we'd better find a more useful example).The Boss FV-500 (or FV-500L - i don't remember if there's any difference) is a stereo volume pedal that works well with guitars AND keyboards, and can also act as a control pedal (expression, swell or whatever) -- except the control pedal mode is not compatible with Clavia products (or, at least, not with my NS2). Still, it is a fine volume pedal, quite large and sturdy, and can be a nice addition to some setup.

title: X Stands, scourge or savior?
post_content: Hello forum!{Warning, the following thread is for entertainment purposes only.Comments contained within are not necessarily shared by the entire forum staff.No keyboard stands were harmed in the making of this thread.Any resemblance to stands, either living or dead, is purely coincidental}I'll share a moderation team inside joke:TheModerationTeam wrote:How can you tell when Hanon has posted another topic?Easy! There's a huge spike in the stats for the rolling eyes emoticon usage throughout the forums....Yes we track thoseHere's another random "roll eyes" thought:Riddle me this Batman:"What costs more to ship, than to actually manufacture?"Oops, wrong Riddler....{please note: Matthew Lesko isnotthe real Riddler. Of course, neither was Jim Carrey}The real Riddler, aka Frank Gorshin"X Stands" (Scourge, or Savior?)No, it's not another bad X-Men sequel, there's way too many of those already.I'm talking about those ironing board stands that seemed to pop up almost over night in the mid eighties, and have been omnipresent ever since.If I had a shiny nickle for every X stand that I've bought over the years, well I'd have a whole bunch of shiny nickles.These are dreadful stands that wobble side to side at the pivot point proportionate to the weight of the keyboard that it supports.I remember playing a Roland A-90 on one that wobbled so bad that we had to write a time signature change halfway through every song to keep it from flying off the stand and injuring someone in the audience....OK, I'm kind of exaggerating there.... there wasn't really an audienceX Stands aren't all bad. They're way better than a pair of cleverly arranged bar stools, and can be "combined into some pretty interesting combinations" {Mojo Jojo redundancy reference}.This combination example graciously shared by simonbeck:Rockin_Arrangement.JPG (36.36 KiB) Viewed 5471 timesThankfully 2012 has brought us some creative alternatives (although I'd much prefer the jetpack that I was promised as a child. When is that coming?)Enough of my ramblings.What are your thoughts?Cheers, Hanonbtw:and that's how we invented the telegraph....

title: RE: X Stands, scourge or savior?

title: About the "unofficial" nature of this forum
post_content: Dear all:since there have been some recent discussions about the nature of this forum and in particular the relationship with Clavia, we the Admins and Moderators of this forum thought it would be useful to clarify some things.First of all, this forum is a purely private user forum of and for Nord Keyboard users, players, and musicians in general. We have no link whatsoever with Clavia or distributors of Nord products. That is, you cannot expect to get official responses, statements, or assistance. Rather, we are all fellow users who devote some of our free time to discuss with other fellow members of this forum.Nevertheless, representatives of Nord and their affiliates might check this website and engage in discussions with users, including providing assistance if they have the time and feel it could be useful. Their contributions are of course greatly valued and contribute greatly to the overall user experience.To make this independent nature of the forum more salient, we put our heads together and by using a new logo on the website restating the "Unofficial" in the title, we hope to avoid further misunderstandings.If you are in the need of support from Clavia or their distributor in your country, I strongly suggest to contact them directly via their support form (http://www.nordkeyboards.com/main.asp?t ... al_support) which will be sent automatically to Nord directly as well as your distributor.But of course it is always a good idea to search this forum or other websites about experiences of other users which can give you hints of how to solve particular problems since your questions might have been asked (and answered) by others already. And we are very grateful to the large number of members that make this forum a very useful resource!In this sense, happy!!The Team

title: RE: About the "unofficial" nature of this forum
post_content: Johannes wrote:If you are in the need of support from Clavia [...], I strongly suggest to contact them directly via their support [...]In my experience, they are very prompt to respond, patient, polite and precise.I've contacted them twice and have been answered within 24 hours each time.First time, I wasn't even a customer yet. Moreover, the answer could have easily been found on their website, and yet they answered me personally.Second time resulted in a week-long conversation about my issue, which turned out was only me being a total noob and yet they still didn't seem to mind.So, I concur: don't hesitate to contact them, they are extremely cool.My country's distributor, on the other hand, while very prompt and polite too, was not very accurate or well informed.

title: Hey you kids, get off of my lawn!
post_content: http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/ ... R820120726reuters wrote:(Reuters) - Comforting news for anyone over the age of 35, scientists have worked out that modern pop music really is louder and does all sound the same.Researchers in Spain used a huge archive known as the Million Song Dataset, which breaks down audio and lyrical content into data that can be crunched, to study pop songs from 1955 to 2010.A team led by artificial intelligence specialist Joan Serra at the Spanish National Research Council ran music from the last 50 years through some complex algorithms and found that pop songs have become intrinsically louder and more bland in terms of the chords, melodies and types of sound used."We found evidence of a progressive homogenization of the musical discourse," Serra told Reuters. "In particular, we obtained numerical indicators that the diversity of transitions between note combinations - roughly speaking chords plus melodies - has consistently diminished in the last 50 years."They also found the so-called timbre palette has become poorer. The same note played at the same volume on, say, a piano and a guitar is said to have a different timbre, so the researchers found modern pop has a more limited variety of sounds.Intrinsic loudness is the volume baked into a song when it is recorded, which can make it sound louder than others even at the same volume setting on an amplifier.The music industry has long been accused of ramping up the volume at which songs are recorded in a 'loudness war' but Serra says this is the first time it has been properly measured using a large database.The study, which appears in the journal Scientific Reports, offers a handy recipe for musicians in a creative drought.Old tunes re-recorded with increased loudness, simpler chord progressions and different instruments could sound new and fashionable. The Rolling Stones in their 50th anniversary year should take note.

title: New MP3 Player on this forum
post_content: Dear all:it has been some time now that I have been looking for a new version of the small MP3 Player plugin used throughout this website.In particular due to the incompatibility of Flash and the iOS, and the general phasing out of Flash in general and moving to HTML5, at some point it will be inevitable. And while I don't have an iPad, it can definitively be fun and is a pity it does not work there.Finally, after long discussions and trying out different solutions, I think to have found the best candidate. But while we ran tests on several machines, OS, and browser combinations, you can never anticipate all potential problems, so I would need your help in order to see if the new player will work for all (or at least 99%) users.Therefore, I implemented the new player for now only on the start/portal site in the left column for the latest two uploaded patches.Only if it turns out to work for everyone I would want to implement it throughout the forum, notable the samples and programs sections, the collections, and also the "My music" forum. And finally also retrospectively change all the existing posts.So I would be very interested if you could just quickly reply to this thread indicating (a) if the new player works on your PC/Mobile/Tablet/whatever, if it works "correctly" (i.e., as the previous player, just playing back the sample), or if the mp3 file is being opened in your audio player or just downloaded. Secondly, I would also be interested in hearing your general opinion on design or whatever you think.I also created a small poll cyou can fill out, also if you have nothing particular to say. You have two votes, one is considered for the functionality, one for your opinion. THANKS!In any case I highly appreciate your feedback as changing the current player will in the end be almost irreversible (or at least a PITA squared).Johannes

title: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: We will never forget you.

title: RE: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: indeed. RIP.

title: RE: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: Have posted about this elsewhere, but it's hard to overstate how much of an influence Lord had on my musical career.In autumn 1990, I was 16 and I'd already done a stint in a Bon-Jovi style covers band playing synths and the odd bit of digital piano and not really liking it. I'd pretty much decided I was going to forget about keyboards entirely and learn guitar or bass. I caught somebody (probably John Peel or Tommy Vance) play Deep Purple's "Speed King" on one of Radio 1's rock shows they used to have back then. I picked up a "best of" LP the next day, and was transfixed that a Hammond organ wasn't that cheesy cinema music instrument after all, but a genuinely powerful keyboard that could take on a guitarist and beat them at their own game. From then on, all keyboards went on the "Hammond" patch and got shoved through a distorted amp, and of course it was only a matter of time before I picked up the real deal, culminating in an A-100, and the Nord Electro for practical gigging purposes.I've grown up and become a bit more refined since then, but if I hadn't discovered Jon Lord's playing, I would have lost interest in keyboards completely and either just be a guitarist or bassist, or not in bands at all. I certainly wouldn't be on this forum.RIP Jon - you will be sadly missed.Edit:Click here for my own mini tribute

title: RE: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: Hah, I was 16 in 1990 too, probably discovered all of this around the same time.Worth posting:[youtube][/youtube]

title: RE: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: Yes that's a shame.  RIP

title: RE: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: I was 15 in 1990 and my life changed after hearing Jon's solo in "Highway Star", the live version of Made in Japan.

title: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: I know that this has nothing to do with issues or anything with the Stage 2 so pardon the indulgence.I was greatly saddened to hear of Jon's passing this morning. He has been an inspiration to me for over 40 years. His playing on Deep Purple in Rock so inspired me as a teenager in the 1970's. Child in Time is still my favourite song of all times. That Organ sound on the iconic song and Album is easily replicated on the Nord Stage 2. I wanted to share the fact that Jon Lord had influenced me for years and I saw him many times when he played with Deep Purple in concerts around Australia. The highlight for me was when he played with the Hoochie Koochie Men at Sydney's iconic "The Basement". He was at his trusty Hammond B3 (it might have been C3 on the night) and was 2 metres away!!! That performance is available on CD/DVD. What a night!So this post is for Jon and all the people around the world who loved his music, his playing and his quiet and humble nature. From that to his history making coupling of the mighty B3 with a Marshall amp, truly makes him unique.It is fitting that the Stage 2 has several organ patches called Jon Lord and they remain my favourite B3 sounds on the Stage 2.You will be missed Jon, but not forgotten.Anyone else have memories of Jon?CheersKevin

title: RE: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: Horacio wrote:I was 15 in 1990 and my life changed after hearing Jon's solo in "Highway Star", the live version of Made in Japan.My band will be covering it at our next gig in tribute.  The vocals will be tough, but it's not Gillan we're paying tribute to.

title: RE: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: He singlehandedly brought the mighty B3 from the church to the concerthall. Rock wouldn't be the same without him.As keyboard players it's hard not to associate a palm smear here and a touch of leslie there and some overdrive across to Jon. A giant.

title: RE: RIP Jon Lord
post_content: Yes, an absolute giant - Rest in Peace! He was the one who make me switch over from Classical / Jazz-Organ to more Rocky tunes when I was a boy. Wanted to play all his great Hammond solos ...

title: Music learning process
post_content: Hello,I'd like to know if, among the great musicians we have on the forum, some of you could give some guidance on how to improve one's music skills, what are the most valuable references, good websites/forums to read ?Nothing replaces experience (practice / listening / trying / playing with others), but the idea here is to talk on the methods/references that could help to maximize the learning process : be more efficient in learning tunes, get more pleasure/freedom while playing.I'll give my modest contribution and hope great answers will enlight this topic !Here is what I would recommend to read, I think it's short and efficient and applies to every musician (not only jazz) :- Jamey Aebersold - The Jazz Handbook- Mark Levine - The Jazz Piano Book-http://forums.allaboutjazz.com/Here what "guides" me these days in my "continuous music learning process" :- I try to choose my tunes carefully and work on the functionnal aspect of harmony on each tune to understand them and memorize patterns that I can apply on different tunes.And you ?

title: RE: Music learning process
post_content: i found Vincent Persichetti's 20TH CENTURY HARMONY to be by far the most useful and interesting book to read.  However, you will need recordings of the works discussed in the examples to gain the most benefit from the book.

title: RE: Music learning process
post_content: Here are some books which I would recommend to study:-Tons of Runs, for the contemporary Pianst by Andy LaVerne-Kenny Barron the Book Releves et Analyses-Michel Petrucciani the Book-Jamey Aebersold -Piano Voicings Vol.41 - Body And Soul-bach two part inventions

title: RE: is this website slow?

This happens to me both at home and at work.As far as I can tell, the forum is running on shared hosting at speicheranbieter.de and the web server it is running on is sometimes not responding. This should be impacting just about any site running on that web server, not just this forum. This is something the hosted should troubleshoot and fix.

title: RE: is this website slow?
post_content: Hi, well I am constantly monitoring the site performance and on Saturday and last tuesday there were some above average load times.As for the server, I changed the DNS in February for two weeks to run a version on a dedicated server and was quite disappointed by the results in terms of improvement even usien xcache and a generous server configuration. So for the moment I switched back, but will keep looking into that. For one thing, phpbb3 plus the addons that are used on this site plus the flash players and portal just require all their server resources plus load time. korgforums just to mention, is extremely fast, but is using plain phpbb2. On average, load time is 4.9sec (SE: 1.8Sec), so 95% of visitors should experience a loading time of the FRONT page of <9 seconds. Anyway, thanks for the comments and I promise I will continue to look into that to ensure a smooth user experience.Johannes
